Journal from Guada. to Guaymal in Sonora, Continued
1832.  May 14  I have mentioned our leaving Santa Isabel and arriving at Tapucan - in a few words for want of room in my last book.  About a league from Santa Isabel is situated the little hamlet or rancho of Chapalilla which we passed as the day was near breaking, and for about 3 leagues our road lay up a bare ascent gently leading towards a wild mountainous and woody district which we entered about 7 o'clock.  At the entrance to "los Cuantos" as this tract is called, the road lies along the side of the hill with 
[?immense?] deep valley or ravines on the left which are covered completely with the Mexican oak which here grows to a considerable size, and a great number of smaller trees and shrubs.  The road for more than three hours

Note Book. No. 2.
John P. Brodie
May 1832

Languangue (upwards of 5000 feet above the plain of Tepic) to the right and the village of Calisco (capital of this province before the Conquest)  to the left we arrived at Tepic about 8 o'clock and stopped at the house of D. Jose Antonio Herrera, consul general for Chile, with whom and W. John McAlpine I had left Guadalacara. 

  I have very often regretted not having taken note of whatever might have appeared strange or interesting on my first going over any part of the Country. - I have travelled this road now so often that it is impossible for me to make any remarks which ocurred  to me on first impressions. - everything is now so common to me, that I cannot but think in spite of me, that they must be as uninteresting to other people as they are to me - However

2.
travelling is dangerous both on account of the bad footing for horses, and the banditti which frequent it.  On leaving the cuanto the country continued mountainous but without wood except on the tops of some of the hills where there are tufts of [?pine?].  I have observed that about this place these tufts are always on the west slope of the hills which are always conical, and the rest of the hill is always covered with grass.  After riding up hill and down dale till 12 o'clock we arrived at the village and Hacienda of San Leonel, romantically and beautifully situated on an elevation with streams of crystalline water on two sides and considerable plantations of wheat, maize, sugar &c surrounding it.  We rested here till 4 o'clock, when we set out and after passing some interesting scenery, and the mountain of

dalena is much more temperate; -- again Mochitille is more warm, and the Plan de Barrancas is warmer still. -- At El Ocote it is even cold sometimes. --  Tetetlan is unsufferable and Santa Isabel only a league distant is again temperate.  The sky is beautifully clear, and for a short part of the year, with the exception of the rainy season, which here lasts from June till September, there is hardly a cloud to be seen on the heavens. --  Very little dew falls, and the climate is here in general dry and healthy. --  On arriving within three or four leagues from Tepec a very Seasonable difference is felt: --  Our clothes were almost wet with the dew, and the mists or "neblinas" which envelop the town and neighbourhood, beat our famed Scotch Mist hollow. --  These Mists are generally in the Nights and will wet a person to

4.  I shall endeavour not to be so remiss in future in other parts of the Country where it may be my lot to travel, but always note down my first impressions, which altho' that must necessarily be sometimes erroneous, will be always open for unclear and correction, and many Circumstances may be noted which otherwise might be passed over on account of being too common by every day's observation of them --  I may mention however, respecting our journey from Guadalahara to Tepic, the the Country is one of the most beautiful and richest districts in the whole Country. -- I say richest in an agricultural point of view, and all the fruits of the Tropics are strikeout: good or may be produced. -- In different places the Climate Varies considerably. .  Thus for instants Tequila is very hot while LaMag-

in the Cities, even altho' they may happen to be of pure Indian race, very rarely or never pass as such.  The arrieras or muleteers are a strong athletic race of men, and in general are the most Sober and honest people in the Country --  This I attribute to the hardships they have to undergo in their long journeys exposed to all the vicisitudes of the weather, which keeps them constantly employed and to the little communication they have with the low classes in the Cities. --  The best dressed of them would be a curiosity at home, and I shall endeavour to give strikeout: you a description of how they are dressed generally, without going to either extremity. --  They are generally mounted on Mules of a Small breed, which is about covered with an immense saddle from which

6.  the skin as quick as a heavy shower of rain. --  The people in the Various towns are on the Haciendas are generally a strikeout: f well made race of people. --   None of them can be Strictly called Indians, and the whites are very few, but you have all the different shades from the one to the other, so mixed and Crossed that it is utterly impossible to make out what proportions they bear --  Some few may be pure Indians, but do not pass as such, neither desire they to do so --  The name Indian is applied by the people of this country almost exclusively to those who live in town by themselves, even supposing they may have a few whites or of mixed blood living among them, but those who reside in the large towns established by the whites, or

crupper (which is indispensable to a mule) are of Common leather, as the Cover of the Saddle, and which when not very old, has generally the appearance of having once been of as dirty brick color. -- The dress of the arriera himself Consists of a pair of white or brown Cotton drawers which reach a little the knee over which are drawn a pair of leather breeches which reach about to the same or not so far, and are open at the knee with peaks hanging down to which, although never used for fastening, are always appended about a dozen of small silver buttons to each leg. --  The breeches are kept up by two or three large buttons of the Same Metal which keep the wastband tight over the haunches. On the legs they wear leather botas a sort of gaiters of goat or deerskin

the animal shows its head like a turtle strikeout:  from within his when he looks out from his shell. The saddle tree is furnished strikeout:  from before with a high pummel rising about 4 to 6 inches, and behind it rises also abruptly to the same height shaped or sounded so as to form the Seat --  Over the tree and understrappings is thrown what are called the mochillas, or cover, which among these people is generally of a Square shape in length about 4 feet and reaching down to cover the belly of the mule. -- This cover is furnished with two large pockets in front in which the arriera Carries whatever necessaries he may require. The stirrups are of wood are although very large are light.  The bit is powerful and is the same as used universally in the Country, and the bridle and

11.  breeches his spurs fastened to his naked heel, and his hat --  the only mourning worn by the arrieras, even the richer Sort of them, and proprietors of large quantities of mules is their botas or gaiters which they Stain black with the beans of the quisache tree.  W.W. Alpin and myself were well lodged and most hospitably treated by all.  Herrera, who is strikeout:  principal partner of the house of Herrera & Ritchie of this place and San Blas.  We had both been clents in the house for a considerable time W.A. here & in San Blas and I in Guadalahara, where the house has also an establishment. --  Tepic is a large town Contg about 12,000inhabitants, and is regularly built.  It formerly was a place of very considerable trade but has now fallen off considerably, and Since they

10.  which are wrapped round the legs and tied above the drawers below the knee. --  On the feet they have mostly Shoes open outside with a large flap on the strikeout: out- inside of the strikeout leg but very often only Sandals, and large spurs weighing about 12 to 16 ounces each.- Some of them indulge themselves with a Shirt, but the generality use what the Call a "Coton", made of coarse woolen stuff striped, which reaches down to the middle of the body or about covers the breast, and leaves exposed the most part of the back and belly to the Sun and air.- Over all this is placed a hat of respectable dimensions as regards brim, sometimes made of palm leaves, and sometimes of coarse woolen stuff.- It is no ways uncommon to see a big fellow on a small mule with its large saddle, tho with no other dress but his leather

13.  pity he should be so fond of embellishing.  His fine story about the Cora Indians with their feather in their heads, and their inventories of their goods and chattels, is all taken from his own imagination.  These poor people are the most abject of any of the races of Indians I have seen, but they have got their peculiarities, the account of which may interest in the description. --  There heads are covered with patale hats or hats made of the leaves of the palm tree, the same as strikeout: all worn by all the Indians of the Country, and altho' they they do wear a sort of fringe of Leather thongs at the Knees of their breeches it is only for ornament and Capt. H. has supposed that they might be used for such purpose as he mentions, at least that the story would do very well to humbug the people at home with. --

12.  first visit to it in 1829, in every Succeeding one, I have observed the place become more and more dull and Solitary. --  Now, more so than ever from the effects of an epidemic disease raging in the town and which is Carrying off from 12 to 16 per day. --  It commences with catarrh and ends with inflamation of the lungs, and the sickness lasts only 2 to 3 days. --  During our stay in Tepic we had three days of Continued and heavy rains which prevented us from proceeding on our journey. --  While the weather was good we took Several walks about the place, and went to the Convent of La Crus which Capt. Hall describes in his work. --  Capt. Hall has got a knack for colouring his descriptions and setting them off in beautiful language, but it is a

15.  they want to take a very long aim and send the arrow far, they sit on their hands, fixing the bow on the soles of their feet, and pulling the arrow and string with their hands, they lay almost on their backs, when they let fly. --  I have seen them often hit a mark of 4 inches I guase at 200 ft. distance.  In fact I never have once known them to miss a mark, and this will bring down a small bird on the wing at a considerable distance. --  Every one carried with him, three or four bags of different sizes, made by themselves of woollen thread of different colors and wrought into curious patterns of eagle, Lion &c, in which they carry their provisions, money &c.  I could find nothing in Tepic worth Calling attention to.  Capt. Halls stories are all made up or exaggerated. --  Going along his description of the place, I shall

14.  They always bring with them their bows, but I never  have once Seen one of them in 'Tepic with an arrow or a knife. --  On enquiry they say that they leave them with the males and women of their party outside of the town. --  At the Saltworks of "Zapotillo" three leagues from San Blas, where they go to buy salt, I have had opportunities of observing them very closely.  They are what we call very "knowing" and are always on the alert from being imposed upon. --  Of a party of 20 or 30 there is generally one at least that can make himself understood in Spanish. --  Their arrows are about 3 feet long, pointed with flint notched, and fastened with thongs to the point, and the but end has got three half feathers to it. --  They are very expert in the use of their arrows, and when

17.  was ever heard of. --  There are a few gardens and orchards in the Suburbs. --  But were I to go on Correcting every embellishment and exaggeration I would never be at an end. --  So I will let it alone, and write my own journal, and endeavour myself to make less use of travellers licence. --  Da. Julia, the young lady whom Capt. Mall mentioned in his account of the last party leaving Sn. Blas, as being so very interesting and not being able to read or write, has expressed her anger against him in plain terms every time his name is Mentioned, and Says she Could read well enough his letter asking her for a lock of her hair, and that he himself knew that well enough -- 21st. May. On this day about 3 P.M. I

16.  note in what he is wrong.--  In the first place Zapollay? and Layula? (of 25 & 20,000 inhabitants each) and Lagos (of 16,000), take from Tepic the precedence which he gives this place, and it is actually the fourth or fifth place of importance in the State instead of being the next to Guada. . --  Coluna, which was annexed to the province of New Galicia at that time, is a city of upwards of 25,000 Souls --  I have visited all of these places, & do not mention things from hearsay. --  In any future travels should I find leisure, from memory I shall endeavour to say something about these places and others. --  As to rows of trees and terraced walks, there is of the former only one place where there is a sort of double avenue of about 300 yds, leading to La Cruz, and of the latter, no such thing

19.  and I had disembarked on the Gulf of Mexico and travelled across the Continent. --  About 2 leagues from Tepic is situated the Village of Lodelamedo, almost smothered with luxuriant Vegetation and so completely overshadowed as to appear a thick forest of Plantains, and tamarind trees. --  The road is very uneven and after Sometimes rising, Sometimes descending, and at othertimes travelling along ravines and beds of rivulets completele Shrouded with the trees, we arrived just at sunset at the brow of the hills, from whence we had a glorious view of the Sea, (still distant upwards of 20 miles) and of the Country all the way to the Coast.  It got immediately too dark to be able to distinguish any thing more, and we began

18.  set out from Tepic in Company with W.W. Alpin and all.  Peter Hamilton, strikeout Captain of the Mauginta Cutter (formerly "Lord Townsend" in the British revenue Service.)  We were all Scotchmen and all young, and altho' accustomed to meet Countrymen every where I go to, strikeout who have visited strikeout three words very different Countries, I Could not help remarking that three young men who had all left their own Country should have met here in such an out of the way place, and which none of us ever expected on leaving our own Country ever to have seen, and in truth never had heard of -- Mr. Alpin Came from Europe round the Cape of Good Hope, and by the way of Calcutta to Sb Blas. --  Hamilton Came round Cape Horn,

21.  possession unclear the time, and is now the property of Doña Manuela widow of Fonsecas and for the Same reason is often called el Rancho de la Viuda. --  The difference in climate between this place and Tepic is very remarkable, and in the rainy Season, it becomes uninhabitable and all its population almost removes strikeout to Tepic.  The Same happens with every place from here to San Blas, and that afternoon we met a good many sickly faces on their way from the unhealthy low Country, where on account of the few days rain, disease and death have been making dreadful havock. --  22d. May --we set out very early and passed the Village of Guanistemla about day break and el Zapotillo in 2 hours afterwards. --  We stopped at

20.  to descend the Palos Marias, so called from the tree of this name with which the mountain Side is Covered, and which grows to immense height and size at this place. -- This place, from the thickness of the forest, is almost dark in the daytime, and now it was so completely so, that without the slightest exaggeration I could not see my hand before my eyes, altho' I held it within an inch from my nose to make the trial.  By chance our horses and mules knew the road with all its turns and about 9 o'clock we arrived with no other accident than my receiving a severe blow on the head from a branch hanging across the road, at the ranch de Fonseca or as it is more generally known "de Manuela" --  This place always has gone by the name of its

of the remainder, more than one half had died whilst the others had removed the best way they could to the interior. --  The Salt is collected from the low ground where first the earth is piled up in small heaps, and afterwards thrown into [[strikeout: a] large troughs, formed of Canes and earth, which Contain water. -- The water is allowed to Strain through the trough (in the manner of a drip stone into a hole dug into the earth below it, from whence it is taken up in gourds strikeout: of or buckets, and poured out on little beds formed of plaster about 3 inches deep, where it is left to evaporate by the heat of the Sun which taking place in a few hours, leaves the Salt behind in pretty large crystals, whence it is collected in bags and carried by mules to the warehouses

22.  La Puenta three leagues from San Blas and where the warehouses of the Zapatillo Saltworks are to Visit a friend who had the charge of them during the two Months that the Salt is collecting. --  Never in my life have I seen such a collection of skeletons or people more dead than alive. --  The Season had been unhealthy over more than other years, and the rain which fell was now evaporating from the marshes and producing such a stench that we were often obliged to hold our noses. --  This accompanied with the hard work of these poor people who are all from the interior, had caused fevers of which strikeout: at least 4 to 10 died every day out of about 500. --  The place now Contained about 200 inhabitants every one sick or sickly, and

25.  has once been in a little better condition but as it has gone to decay has strikeout:  been never been repaired. --  Even the roof of the Church which had fallen in, has never been put on again, and while I was here three years ago it was in the same condition as it is now.  Mass is said in one end where a part of the roof is still standing.  As the Vessel in which we were to sail for Guaymas, would not be ready for Sea for somedays, I accepted Hamilton's invitation to live on board his vessel in the bay in the meantime where it would be cooler than on shore and I would not be exposed to fevers, mosquitos and unclear besides every sort of Verminstrikeout:  to found in such a coastal climate. --  On shore every body was sick or dying, and without equivocation or going beyond

24.  where it is stored in bulk. -  25,000 loads of 300 libs each can be collected in the short time that the harvest continues, from this district, which is however pretty exclusive. -- The unclear paid to the laborers is one dollar for every 300 lbs. out of which he has got to defray the expense of his implements and every thing connected with the Manufacture. --  We found San Blas almost as sickly as La Puenta, and nearly deserted by its populations. --  San Blas is situated in the top of an isulated rock at the distance of about half a mile from the beach and is certainly one of the most unclear places you Can suppose. --  It strikeout: is must be a miserable prospect indeed for one arriving from a long voyage. --  The town

27.  "Aguila", American Schooner in which we were to Sail. --  I went a fishing inside the harbour one morning with Capt. Barry of the Vulture and Hamilton. --  At one drag of the net we Caught about 200 fish of different sorts, the largest weighing about 3 lbs, and having made presents of most part, we breakfasted well off some and Salted the remainder. --  The anchorage ground at Sn Blas is an open road Stead and exposed to almost every wind but the S.E. are the most dangerous; --  when it blows hard the only remedy is to put out to sea unless you bear great confidence in your Cables. --  Sunday May 24h.  (This day eight years I landed in Alvarado from Greenock). --  The Aguila Sailed at

26.  the truth, I may Safely assert that no one can withstand the effects of such a climate for a whole rainy Season, not even those born on the  spot. --  The prevalent disease is what is called "faios" or tertean ague, the frequent attacks of which brings down strikeout: to the Constitution so that the slightest fever carries the Victim off --  After the fever comes on Strong at the beginning and is followed by the "frios" which consumes the patient slowly until he Can no longer bear, and falls a prey to them. --  May 22d. to 24h.  On board the Manquita, sometimes going ashore for a few hours, and sometimes passing the day on board  the English brig Vulture which arrived from Gibraltar on the 24th., and on board the

29.  wholesome dews, to sleeping in a small cabin where there were other five, and being burned up in a temperature seldom below 100°. --  On the 28th. we passed the Island of Isabella distant from SnBlas 4.5 miles. --  It is uninhabited, and has no fresh water, but it is frequented by boats and Canoes from SnBlas which come to fish for tortoise, and are abundant. --  There is a small brackish lake in the Centre about which are sea fowl in Such Numbers that they can be knocked down with sticks --  The island is a bare rock and on the west side is a small bay with good anchorage ground.  on the afternoon we distinguished to the S.W. one of the Maria Islands --  29th.  In the Morning no land in sight except some low

28.  5'o'clock this morning until which hour the land breeze began to blow very gently from the Shore. --  There strikeout: are were 5 passengers unclear Myself, -- Namely W. Alpin, 2 unclear, and 2 Natives of the Country, one of them a member of the Senate at Mexico and returning to his own State after his 4 years attendance to his legislative duties.  The weather during the whole Voyage was very Variable, and we were becalmed Some Part of every day, during which the heat was almost unsufferable.  Our vessel being so very small only 45 tons, and out decks crowded with lumber, the boat, 2 canoes, and a Carriage it was impossible for us to pursue a walk of more than 5 feet in length. --  I preferred sleeping on deck the whole voyage & running the risk of the un-

31.  Season of the strong winds from the S.E. as it is impossible beat out to sea, and there is no remedy but riding it out.  The only vessels in the Port are the American Ship "James Monroe," taking in Brazil wood, and a small Mexican Schooner.  On the 31st. it blew almost a gale all day which made our little bark pitch and toss most furiously. --  I observed tonight two or three of the most beautiful exhalations or falling stars, and never have seen these phenomena in Such splendour -- They fell gently a considerable distance leaving a clear streak of light and then appeared to burst, throwing out a number pf other lights each exceeding in brilliancy the one from which they proceeded, and resembling the

30.  strikeout Coast of Sinaloa, scarcely Visible, but as the day advanced we could distinguish Varios headlands, and Mountains in the interior, and the rocks and islands which form the Port of Mazatlan right ahead, off which we arrived about 2 o'clock and hoisted the boat out whilst W. Alpin, one of the Mexicans, and the Capt went ashore with a few boxes. --  The port of Mazatlan contains only a few huts and two or three buildings which deserve the name of houses, and has a Miserably unhealthy climate, and on shore the people are dying like rotten sheep.  The entrance to the bay has an appearance wild and picturesque, but dreamy and uncomfortable, as is almost as much exposed as SnBlas, and is more dangerous during the

33.  the island of la Catalana and the Coast of California, and without any thing worthy of remark, and passing the other islands of Monserrate & el Caunser we strikeout: a crossed the gulf and came in sight of Oake Karo at the entrance to the port of Guaymas on the morning of Monday the 8th. June, and anchord in the harbour after a passage of 13 days, about 3 o'clock in the afternoon --  We might have caught plenty of dolphin on the Voyage, had not strikeout: th one of the Sailors very foolishly struck a large shark with the unclear, which of course the monster carried away --  This was the largest Shark I had ever seen, and had our vessel been larger we might have easily Caught it, -- but it would have

32.  bursting of a sky rocket. --  On the 1st. June we Came in Sight of the Coast of California and next morning were off the Island of Ceraloo, which contrary winds, currents and calms kept us in sight of yill the afternoon of the 4th. --  The heat during these dead Calms or "calmachiches" as the Spanish Call them, is very severe and the thermometer always stood in the shade at 90°. to 100°. --  In the Sun where we placed the Thermometer, it rose to 125°. which was the whole extent of the one we had on board (a spirits of wine green house thermometer.)  We passed the various islands of Ceraloo, Espirito Santo, San. Diego, and SantaCruz. --  These are all uninhabited, have no fresh water and are bare & barren strikeout: and on the 5th  Sailed between

35.  islands. --  The island of Pajaros (so called from the number of birds which are on it) lies at the mouth of the harbour, and inside ar those called the Ardilla, almagres, &c --  We found Guaymas in a state of revolution, and besides, threatened to be attacked by the Yaqui Indians, and  everybody almost in a state of alarm and preparing for the defense of their houses and property. --  Were it not for the Vessels in the harbour, the Port of Guaymas to a person arriving from the interior might be taken for a Mountain lake. --  The town is small and contains about 20 or 25 houses and a great many hovels & huts which do not deserve the name of houses. --  We were lodges in the house of Messes MacDuff & Co.

34.  knocked our deck to pieces. --  We picked up a turtle of about 100 lbs weight one day, off which we fared well on steaks and soup. --   We might have Caught plenty but people living on that Coast, and the Sailors will hardly eat them, and are almost the same with them as the people on the North Coast of Ireland are with respect to Salmon, where they make a bargain with the strikeout: peopl Masters with whom they go to Serve, not to give them this fish more than a limited number of days in the week. --  Delicious as turtle eating is, one soon gets tired of it. --  The Port of Guaymas is one of the best on the Coast, and no harbour can be more Secure. --  the entrance is beautiful, and the bay Contains a good many

37.  were surprised and taken by about 20 men of the place with [strikeout: of]] an ex-clerk of the Customhouse at their head, who proclaimed the strikeout: place port to be in favor of General Santanna in Vera Cruz, for the removal of the Present Ministry in Mexico.  A Capt. Tobas had declared himself for the Same in Petic and with about 40 men had taken possession of that place which contained about 12,000 inhabitants. --  Ramirez, the man who has taken the head in this revolution here, not enjoying a very good opinion among the people of Guaysmas, on the Morning of the 11th. drew the guns to the top of the hill where he posted them, and as Tobas was said to be on the road to this, he very easily took charge of the Customhouse

36.  and hospitably treated by Mr Geowand and W. James Duff --  Lat. 24°, 58'  Residence in Guaymas and Journey in to Interior --  There is a small hill close on the beach and in the midil of the town, strikeout: which altho' it has only a and the miserable hovel on the top of it is dignified with the name of fortress, where the Mexican flag is displayed on Sundays and holidays and when any Vessel enters or leaves the Port --  The guns, four in number, were situated at the front of the hill on the mole where the guard consisting of about half a dozen fellows almost without shirts to their backs, were posted --  On the 10h, at strikeout about 10 at Night, they

39.  were kept constantly alarmed and on the alert till the morning of the 23d. when we received the news that the Yaquis in number about 2000 had attacked a Small village three leagues off Called the Rancho de San Jose de Guaymas and containing about 200 inhabitants.  strikeout: This  All the women and children in the place fled to the shipping in the harbour and to the islands where they sheltered themselves in tents erected in the best way the hurry of the moment would permit, and I never saw such a hullabaloo, of trunks removing, women and children Screaming and running about, and the men, some trying to escape, others setting out armed to the Rancho, whilst the remainder prepared themselves for the defense of the place. --

38.  and the funds in it amounting to about $13,000. --  The lower classes are always ready to take advantage of any disturbance, and showed evident inclinations to have a general Sacking of the place, and as Ramirez had not the means to protect the property third of the Inhabitants with his slender force, which from report, had the Same intentions, we were all under the necessity of looking after ourselves and remaining under arms strikeout Constantly Night and day. --  The Yaqui nation of Indians were also threatening an attack on the town with their common purpose of destroying the whites --  Tobas entered on the 17th. and after Seizing about 10 thousand dollars, left the place again for the Purpose as he said of attacking the Yaquis --  We

41.  American for our Commander while I with 11 men had the charge of the door for 4 hours from 10 o'clock till two __  Another Party of 5 were posted strikeout on the roof of the house, and we let out a patrole of 5 men more,  --  allowing all the rest to sleep if they pleased till two o'clock with their arms by them.  About 12 o'clock it was reported that the Indians were entering the town,  --  the Centinel at the Fort gave the alarm, and every soul in the place woked to our house or to the mole to escape in the boats. --  Some of the men got off in Womens clothes, and such was the Consternation that Some of the women who had remained in the town, ran into the water up to their necks.  The report was occasioned by two

40.  Ramirez desired the foreigners in the place to march to the Rancho also, or deliver our arms, but as we had reasons for not placing too much confidence in him or his garrison, we set him at defiance, and most of us met in Mr. Duff's house where a great number of trunks and bales of goods had been removed, and with Servants and altogether Mustered strikeout: ab 45 Men all well armed --  Our house is on the north side of the plaza and directly in front of the fort where was a 12 pounder pointed towards us --  Seeing us determined to resist, he yielded and afterwards showed a wish to have an understanding with us that we might be more united. --  At night he gave up the Sign and Countersign, as we named W. Anderson an

43.  in Case of the Yaquis making their appearance, when the fool Commanding the fort imagining that the guns were to be employed against it in Case of troops of the government arriving, brought a long eighteen pounder to bear right on her decks. --  On remonstrating with him and aprising him that there was no such intention, he again wheeled the gun round but made Capt. Frazer draw farther out again and not lay opposite the fortress --  There is not Church nor Jesuit in Guaymas, and Sunday is only known by the colons housed at the Fort and the Vessels in the harbour --  The foundation of a church had been fact laid, but the work appears to go on very slowly.  The dead are buried without

42.  huts having been set on fire at the Skirts of the town, but luckily is was without foundation. --  We were kept in constant alarm all night until the next Morning (June 21st) when we secured strikeout: the news intelligence that the Indians had retired after losing about 20 killed and a considerable number wounded -- of the people of the Rancho only one was killed, and two stragglers taken by the Indians and who were found hanged on the trees this Morning.  The "Sir John Keane" an English Schooner from Valparaiso lying in the harbour, had drawn near in Shore, and Capt. Frazer had brot his two guns to bear on that side and had them well loaded with grape and Canister shot, so that he might rake the beach

45.  strikeout: to no swamps or low grounds, and it does not rain above 3 or 4 days in the whole year. --  During the day there is always a slight refreshing breeze, but at night after it has died away the heat is almost unbearable and altho' the thermometer falls this season to 90°. or 92°, (from 98°. to 100°. at which it is during the heat of the day) it is much more oppressive at Night. --  It must be recollected that the thermometer hangs in a room as Cool as any in Guaymas.  The inhabitants as is the Case in all places in the Country, are mostly strikeout mixt breed, and of all the shades of color from the african black and the Indian to the european white. 1824.  March 27th.  Sailed from Greenock this day on the Brig Jane, Capt. John Leitch for Vera Cruz, Mexico. --  I cannot say that I was sorry to leave my native country, altho' at the same time I could not help being affected at the thoughts of leaving relations and friends for such a distant country, but I was young, having just completed my seventeenth year, and my hopes high, so that any reluctance I may have felt at parting, was more than counterbalanced by the strong desire for seeing foreign places and in particular the interesting country for which we were bound.  I then also fully expected to revisit Scotland within four or five years. --  The Jane, a vessel of 119 tons, is not well fitted for passengers, and less so for their accommodation.  In warm latitudes, the cabin being extremely Small. --  Besides myself there were other two passengers, -- Mr. Neil Campbell from Greenock and Mr. Frederick Staines from Glasgow. --  We sailed with a fine breeze from the N.E. --  Stept into the boat at exactly 12 minutes from 11 o'clock A.M. --  1/2 past one passed the pretty little village of Dunoon on the north side of the River, and the Clough

after it a buoy; the Captain ordered the boat down thinking that there might be Something or other affixed to the buoy, but there was only a piece of rope. --  On the way back with the boat the Sailors picked up 600 quills made up in quarters. --  6 o'clock still in sight of Ireland. --  Very little wind -- nearly becalmed: -- about 7 o'clock wind freshened from the N.W. --  9 o'clock Wickliffe Lighthouse to the left. --  Went to bed about ten and shortly the wind began to blow very hard. --  Could not sleep and got quite sick. --  30th.  2 A.M.  got out of bed very sick.  Saw Tusker lighthouse on the farthest S.E. point of Ireland distant about 15 miles and bearing E. by N. ---  About dawn 14 sail in sight, mostly homebound; --  2 of them passed close by us. --  I hung my head over the leaside till the sickness left me which was  till about 2 o'clock.  Took Suns median altitude:  Lat. 51°. 21'. --  (Whoever reads this I daresay will laugh at my noting having taken the Sun altitude with my head to leaward and vomiting all the while; --  but the Capt and Mate, not I, made the observations) -- The vessel heaving and pitching so much that it is impossible to walk about.  The Captain says it is the finest weather

lighthouse on the S. --  2 o'clock passed the village of Inverkip. --  1/2 past 3, past Toward Lighthouse and Castle the seat of Kirkman Finlay Esqr. --  Spoke the Holy Lock sealane Cutter -- Thompson,  -- 6 guns and well manned, cuising to prevent smuggling. -- 4 o'clock off Bute. --  1/2 past 4 off Cumbrays. --  strikeout: P off Arnan which we had not yet past when we went to bed. --  Staines got very sick.  28th Sunday.  unclear at 5 o'clock and I saw the sun rise over old Scotland for the last time for many years by me:  only past in Sight to Mull of Galloway.  The coast of the Island opposite and many houses along the shore looking beautiful in the morning Sun. --  Isle of Man in sight ahead. --  A brisk breeze all day from the N.E. till about four o'clock when it fell off and we were fairly becalmed till about 8 o'clock when it began to blow fairly briskly from the N.W.  Campbell sick. --  Observed the two lights on the Gulf of Mann; they looking very pretty at night being revolving lights. --  29th Monday. --  Rose about 1/2 past 5 and no land in sight in any direction. --  A great many birds flying about, gulls and wild ducks;  a little bird like the moss cheaper lighted on the deck and rigging and kept about us all day. --  A black floater had us in the afternoon and immediately

The weather continuing beautiful: --  a very considerable difference in the temperature observable. --  Thermometer in the cabin 68°. -- --  The mate saw a shark this afternoon. --  7th. Wednesday. --  Weather the Same. --  a large Turtle alongside,  but soon dived. --  8th.  Thursday. --  The forenoon a swallow flew about the vessel a long time. --  Another or the Same hovered about us in the evening and lighted in the boat at the Stern, and about a minute afterwards Campbell had it in his hand. -- He caught it asleep.  He let it away, but it almost immediately returned to its former place in the boat.  A good many birds called sheerwaters flying about. --  9th. Friday. --  Heavy rains since yesterday evening.  About 8 P.M. as standing by the binnacle a tremendous flash of lighting unaccompanied by thunder, enlightened the decks So much that the minutest object was distinguishable.  The rain fell in torrents. -- not a breathe of wind, -- the lighting flashing about in all quarters, & sometimes breaking at the mast head, sometimes at the anchor, and once at the stern so strongly

he ever had. --  31. --  Wind the Same, and making good progress. --  April 1 st. -- Wind changed and contrary. --  2d. -- Lat. by observation 46°.20'. --  in the afternoon nearly becalmed.  3d.  These three days, a good many vessels in Sight but all at considerable distances. --  4th Sunday. --  A vessel coming up ahead.  Made all haste and wrote a few lines to my Uncle. --   hoisted a signal to speak her, but she showed Dutch Colony, -- Cape Finistere in Spain, the most westerly point of Europe, and also some parts of the Coast of Portugal, distant by our reckoning 57 or 58 miles, -- scarcely visible on the horizon. --  A vessel in sight to the N.W. distant 8 or 10 miles: -- only the masts Visible, -- the hull below our horizon: -- seemingly steering the Same Course as we are. --  5th. Monday.  The vessel seen yesterday and now much nearer appears to be a Logger as the Sailors call this sort, and much used by the Moors, Algerians, &c.  Lat. by observation in 48°.13'. ---  I perceived in the evening Jupiter to be  very near the moon and thought there might be an eclipse of the former and sat up on purpose to observe. --  Exactly at 12 minutes from

17th.  Saturday.  We have at last got fairly into the trade winds. --  The wind being right astern and the spanker or mainsail not drawing, we have got the awning over the mainboom which is comfortable.  The heat in the Sun is very severe. --  Thermometer in the Shade 72°.  In the Sun 88°. --  I intended to have kept one account of our own reckoning, but on account of sickness at the commencement of the Voyage I could not keep it, and since then have  not been able to find out the longitude, and both Captain and mate refuse to tell as they keep separate reckonings. --  Sunday 18th. --  Saw the Sun rise today with such beauty as I have never before witnessed.  Two swallows lighted on the forechains.  A few flying fish seen now and then. -- of different sizes from 1 to 2 inches long to 10 or 12 --  A great many beautiful fishes called Bonitos following up close to the Vessel: --  se two baits but they would not take. --  Weather continuing fine, but little wind; seldom make more than 5 knots.  Monday 19th.  Crossed the Tropic of Cancer today in Longitude 27° 25'. --   The Sailors got the forenoon to themselves. -- a comical old man-o'-war's-man called Dan equipped himself to represent Neptune

that we all feared there was some damage done.   I had never till now been so terrified. --10th. Saturday.  Still rainy, wind blowing fresh and the waves washing over every minute. --  Cleared up towards the afternoon and a great many swallows flying about and lighting on the Vessel. --  A good many porpoises sporting about, some jumping fairly out of the water; they are from four to five feet in length. --  11th. Sunday.  This is now the third Sunday we have been at Sea, but have not got tired yet nor lost patience. --  A Sail in sight to the N. steering the Same course as us. --  12th.  Monday. --  Hardly a breath of wind and heat severe.  Thermometer 80°. --  A dark colored butterfly fluttered about us a good while this afternoon but we could not catch it. --  13th. -- Nothing in particular.  Wind contrary.  14th. --  Plenty of Swallows.  Wind the Same.  15th.  The Vessel mentioned on the 11th still in sight. --  A brig under British Colors passed us sailing to the S.E.  16th.  Friday.  Beautiful weather, very hot.  Lat by Obs. 35°.39'.  Thermom. 83°. in the Sun. --

to the forecastle where they made me seat myself on what I afterwards found to be a plank set across a large bucket of water.  I was then saluted with a tarry mop in my face filled with a grease pitch &c. --  I refused to pay the fine which they wanted to exact (a gallon of rum) after this rough treatment at which I had got confoundedly offended, but as I was afraid of something worse, on hearing the order to get the block and tackle ready on the yardarm to give me a ducking, I was glad to comply with their wishes. --  The tar was then scraped off my face with a piece of old hoop iron, and saluted now with a kiss that is a rough prick on the chin with a nail which Neptunes spouse had stuck into a piece of leather and put over her chin. --  I was then washed down with a bucket of water thrown over me, but I managed to jump up before the plank was drawn from under me and saved myself from a ducking the tub over which I had been seated. --  The appearance of old Dan was so ridiculous and grotesque that I hardly think

and another of the hands personate his wife. --  A large piece of tarpauling was hung across the Vessel at the foremast so that we could not see their movements. --  Three strong fellows with cutlasses came aft and ordered us below, and as it happened to be dinner time, we made no objections. --  A little after twelve the rattling noise of one of the gun Carriages rolling on the deck, and strikeout: the a rough voice calling out "Captain, ahoy" informed us we might suspect something. --  The Captain went on deck and after persuading or trying to persuade the men not to meddle with us, but to no purpose, Neptune retired? in his Carriage but speedily returned. --  I was convinced the whole was only a frolic and would have no bad consequences and had no objections to a little fun; -- but Campbell opposed himself strongly and even got possession of a brace of loaded pistols. --  We persuaded him with difficulty to submit, which he at last did. --  Two fellows fantastically dressed and painted came below and carried him off blindfolded.  In about a quarter of an hour they returned as it was my turn. --  They Carried me blindfolded on deck and making me seat myself on a gun Carriage, I was dragged

to the top: -- I was kept there for about an hour and remained very quiet in the speculation of being released, but was mistaken.  I was obliged to give them half a gallon of rum and afterwards to have the liberty of the Ship. --  Great numbers of flying fish about; as they can only fly while they are wet they very soon return to their proper element. --  A swallow followed us all day. --  A sail in right astern making on us. --  Wednesday 21st.  The vessel astern proves to be an English Brig. --  We slackened sail a little till she got up to us, which was about Sunset and we had some little conversation with the speaking trumpet. --  She proved to be the "Cossack, Capt. Frazer, from Liverpool to Honduras, out 26 days. --  Longitude by their reckoning 33° W. by S. 33°25'. --  She had two passengers, and very soon got ahead of us. --  Thursday 22d. --  The Cossack still in sight far to the southward --  Numbers of flying fishes; -- one struck against one of the Sailors hats and fell on the deck and we had it cooked for supper. --  It was not so large as a herring but thicker; -- the wings or fins about 2 1/2 inches long, and

any description can give any idea of him.  His only dress was a piece of tarpauling around his middle; his head covered with big pieces of ropeyarn tied to his hair; tremendous whiskers and bear of oakum and all his body painted with black and red stripes. --  He was seated on a gun Carriage with a harpoon in his hand in place of a trident.  His spouse made not a less whimsical figure than he did: --  her mouth was covered with a piece of strong leather driven full of nails with the points outward. --  Staines strikeout: his turn came next and he had to go through the same ceremonies as myself, but he could not save himself from the ducking as they managed to get the plank from under him. --  Two of the hands were then Soused and handled rather more roughly than we were. --  Tuesday 20th. --  I was sitting on the main top this forenoon reading "the Incas" when I observed on of the hands coming up the rigging,  -- the Captain called to me to run and I tried to escape by the other side when another fellow me there with a rope and made my feet fast to the Shroud, while the other tied my head

Thursday 29th.  A very heavy sea running since Saturday, so as to make it impossible to write, and difficult to move about without falling.  On Monday while writing, desk and strikeout: everything all capsized and spilt the ink and dirtied every thing. --  A large ship of war past us yesterday distant about seven miles steering N.N.E.. --  Every day some large brown birds flying about. --  Scarcely  a day has passed without seeing birds of some sort or other. --  Another sail passed us yesterday Sailing to the S.W. --  Lat. by observ. 16°.45'. Long. 54°.39'. --  Friday 30th.  A great quantity of sea weed floating continually past us, -- proceeding from the gulph of Florida.  Swallows flying about, and great numbers of them flying fish.  Lat. by observ. 16°.50' Longs 57°.3-'.  Sea still running high.   Saturday 1st. May.  A number of birds called by the sailors "Mother Grays Chickens" flying about us, they are in appearance resembling the swallow, with a white spot on the back near the tail, and the rest of the back of a dark orange color:  the remainder of body and tail is black: --  their manner of flying is the same as the swallows. --  Lat. 17°. 2'. Long. 59°.58'.  Sunday 2d.  We expected today to come within sight of land, and Campbell and me went to the fore topgallant yard to look out.  Two fellows came and lashed Campbell's hands and feet to the shrouds and until he promised to pay his half gallon they

they make tolerably good eating.  I shall endeavour now to keep the ships reckoning that I know the longitude. --  It will serve to exercise myself in the lessons in Navigation which I received at school. --  Lat. by obs. 19°.54'; Log. 35°.46'. W  Friday. --  Nothing particular -- flying fishes as usual; one flew on board.  Lay. 19°26' Long. 38°27' --  Saturday, very hot.  thermometer in the Sun 88°. Lat. 18°.48'. Long. 40°.54'.  A fish called the baracuda passed us chasing some flying fish flying along swiftly two or three feet above the water and the Baracuda almost close under them with its head nearly out of the water. --  The poor little fishes dipped themselves in the water and rose again immediately but I have no doubt but some one of them was eaten up. --  The chase continued So until they got out of sight.  The Baracuda is about 5 or 6 feet long with a large ugly head,  -- white belly and black back. --  It is said to be very poisonous. --

of Saona in the afternoon distant about 10 miles.  Immense numbers of strikeout: fly sea fowl flying around. -  Thursday 6th.  Cape Mongow in St. Domingo in the forenoon distant about 3 miles; the land seemed very high and is seen a great way off. --  Passed the Island of Beata distant about 10 miles; --  it appears to be a broken rock, and at 4 P.M. the island or isolated rock of Altavela distant about 3 miles, the Island of St. Domingo all the while in the distance. --  Immence flocks of birds called by the sailors "boobies" almost sufficient to darken the air, -- unclear part Sto. Domingo in the evening. --  Saturday 8th  Hove in sight of Jamaica in the forenoon. --   A pilot boast came off about 3 o'clock with 6 negroes, -- and hailed us if we wanted a pilot; on being answered in the affirmative they hoisted out their Canoe, & three of them got into it and paddled towards us with amazing swiftness. --  The Canoe is made out of the trunk of a tree hollowed out about two feet wide and 15 or 16 feet in length. --  The negroes were almost naked, their only dress being a coarse woolen shirtt of the stuff used at home for horsecloths, -- one or other of them wore wide cotton drawers.  We got one of them on board, and gave the others in consequence of their clamours, a piece of

did not let him loose.  Plenty of birds flying about called by the sailors "boatswains" from the circumstance of their having a long tapering tail like a marlinspike. --  They appear when flying to measure  from tip to tip of the wings about from 5 to 6 feet. --   Two large fishes sporting at some distance, and spouting up the water into the Air 30 to 40 feet. --  About 12 o'clock got in sight of the island of Antigua. --  I could never have believed before that such anxiety and pleasure could be experienced at the expectation of seeing land and in the realization of the prospect. --  The horizon being rather hazy we did not see the land until within 15 or 16 miles. --  We made up in front about 3 o'clock, and could distinguish the fort and standard, houses, trees, windmills &c.  The island seems to be about the size of the Isle of Man and has somewhat the Same appearance from a distance. --  Passed the west point about 8 o'clock. --  Off the small island of Redondo at 12 o'clock. --  Monday 3d.  No land in sight.  Plenty of birds and flying fishes. --  exceptionally hot.  Thermom. in the sun stood at 96°.  A sail right ahead steering to the southward, apparently a Frenchman.  Wednesday 5th.  The island of Mona in sight at 5 A.M. bearing S. by W. Passed the island

with Venetian blinds and elegantly painted.  The Governors house is superb with rows of Cocanut trees in front down to the waters edge. --  The largest ships can steer close in shore, so that with a good spring one could almost jump to land. --  A number of officers came on board in boats and Canoes manned by negroes, -- all enquiring for news. --  Their sickly countenances startled us -- all pale ass death. --  The shore up the bay to Kingston is beautiful,  -- the verdure enchanting.  Anchored in Kingston harbour at 12 o'clock. --  Plenty of black women came on board enquiring for clothes to wash; but we were given to understand that they offered their services in other ways. --  Went ashore in the afternoon and sauntered through the town. --  Kingston is a large place, but it will be useless to try to give my description of it as I shall have no time to make observations. --  The streets are lined on both sides with Piazzas,  -- the houses are commodious and airy, -- the upper storeys all having large wide corridors with blinds, keeping the interior apartments cool and pleasant,  -- but the streets are far from clean, and I am told that in rainy weather they are almost impassible. --  It has not rained here since December. --  Sunday is

salt beef and a few biscuit, with which they appeared extremely contented.  Out pilot seems a very intelligent fellow and says he is happy notwithstanding his being a slave. --  He says he gets five shillings currency a week to himself, and altho' by application he could soon muster as much money as purchases his liberty, he prefers being a slave, the free negroes being more restricted in Jamaica and even during sickness must either work or starve, -- besides paying taxes. --  Campbell wished to amuse himself with him but found him too much. --  He asked "When does the sun set in Jamaica"? and  was answered, "When it do go down." --  How long do black people live here?  "Till der time come and den they do die, -- and he laughed heartily at his own wit. --  We hove to all night as the land breeze sets in, and the coast is dangerous to approach in the dark.  Sunday 9th.  Made sail at 4 A.M. and stood in shore. --  Numbers of canoes passed us going a-fishing, each manned by three negroes.  About 9 we passed Port Royal. --  It is the prettiest place I ever saw; -- indeed the verdure of the island is magnificent and exceeds in beauty any thing I could ever have imagined. --  Some of the houses are built on pillars, and most open all round

into 4 pieces called here maccaroni, 8 ten penies, and 16 fivepences, which is the smallest coin; -- there is no copper money. --  The oranges were mine for fivepenny, and the pineapple a fivepenny a piece. --  Busy endeavouring to discharge and be in time to Sail tonight, and got some negroes hired to assist the crew, who were mostly all drunk and fit for nothing, -- but at 6 in the evening there still remained about 40 boxes to put ashore. --  Wednesday 12th.  4 A.M.  Convoy and fleet getting under weigh at Port Royal. --  Yet our remaining goods ashore by 5 o'clock, cleared out at the customhouse by 8 and got under weigh by 9 o'clock. -- A little black boy came on board with the pilot, and as we imagined him to be his son, was allowed to remain.  When we got clear out he told the Captain he wanted to go to London with him. --  He is a smart boy about 10 years of age and the Captain Says that were he sure he was free he would take him along with us. --  At Port Royal by noon; -- the fleet about 3 miles ahead but on the outside of a long reef of rocks and shoals which we have to beat round. --  At 6 o'clock put the pilot ashore, and the little boy not to be found till after about an hour's search the mate got him concealed in the hold among the cargo; -- he very sorry to go ashore. --  The fleet a far

allowed the Slaves from all over the island for their market day, and the streets were crowded with them. --  Every white person has a very sickly appearance, and the appearance altogether of the place is not that of Content or Comfort; -- I should be sorry to be obliged to remain here, and every one I have spoken with appears to be disgusted with his situation and would leave the place. --  Every merchant has a separate wharf in the harbour, and we had some difficulty in getting our way back to the vessel, as all the gates were shut.  Monday 10th.  Remained on board, apecting to discharge a part of our Cargo which remain here, -- taking a note of the boxes and bales as they go ashore; --  We are anxious to get ready in time for the Convoy which Sails on Wednesday for Vera Cruz.  Numbers of Canoes with spice and ginger beer, oranges, pines, sweet limes &c. coming alongside.  Tuesday 11th.  Went ashore this afternoon and took a walk through the town.  Bought a few oranges and pineapples in the fruit market which is well supplied with many sorts of fruit till now unknown to us but by description. --  The Current Coin is all Spanish. --  The dollars is six shillings and eightpence Currency and is divided

adjacent island who come to the turtle fishing.  Lightning again at night to the northward.  Monday 17th. --  We are far from safe in our defenseless state in these seas, and I do not feel altogether comfortable at being left without our consort.  Pirates still infest these seas, principally from the island of Cuba where they are sort of tolerated by the authority. --  About two years ago, the Alexander, Capt. Ferguson from Greenock was taken by Pirates hereabouts, and the Capt. hung upon the yard arm. --  He was a fine young man, married a very short time before that voyage, and very well known to our Captain,  The Steward also was killed and the mate and rest of the crew were put ashore on the island of Puerto Rico. --  Birds of many different sorts and sizes flying about.. --  Tuesday 18th.  Fine weather and a good breeze; -- we were becalmed about 2 hours last night.  Wednesday 19.   The mate caught a booby asleep in the jolly boat last night and kept it till this morning. --  The body is about the size of a blackbirds, but the bill is about 2 inches long, and the wings about 2 1/2 feet from tip to tip. --  The color is a dark dirty brown, with the front of the head? white: --  it is webfooted. --  A sail in sight ahead keeping upon the wind. --  We do not like the appearance of her, but keep our course. --  She put about before the wind, and must be a first rate Sailer as in the evening she was

way to the southward. --  8 P.M. not a breath if wind; let down an anchor to prevent our being carried in shore by the current which runs strong. --  Thursday 13th.  No fleet in sight this morning very light winds. --  A few dolphins sporting about. --  Becalmed again in the evening.  Friday 14th.  4 A.M. little wind.  A pretty good breeze sprung up about 10 o'clock and we are getting on finely. --  A large shark following our wake; let out a bait but he would not take. --  Two large pelicans flew close over us --  Saturday 15th.  1/2 past 4 A.M. Out of sight of Jamaica; --  no land in sight; -- wind continues favorable. --  No fleet in sight and doubtful if ever we overtake it. --  A great number of fishes called by the sailors "skipjacks" jumping out of the water. --  This evening deal of lightning.  To the northward it had the appearance of the reflection of a large fire.  Sunday 16th.  A sail in sight astern Sailing to the W. --  Passed the Island of Grand Cayman famous in former times from the Buccaneers who peopled it; -- distant about 4 miles.  The land is low and level, but beautifully green. --  We saw no appearance of houses or of its being inhabited, and I understand is only frequented by boats from the

since we passed the Madera Islands, has been from the S. or within a point of it, has this afternoon shifted to the N. --  As the mate was boiling some pitch in the cook house this afternoon, it caught fire and as the kettle was lashed to the fireplace, it was all in a strikeout: fl blaze before it could be removed. --  It caused us some fright, but in the end the only harm dome was to the poor cook who received the whole of the burning pitch on his feet in the hurry of removing it, which made him set up a tremendous yell in Gaelic. --  By the Bye, all our crew including the Captain, and with the exception of the mate and Carpenter, are highlanders.  Saturday 22d.  We were becalmed last night again for three or four hours, and there was very little wind the rest of the night. --  The dew which fell last night was sufficient to wash the deck with. --  Sounded several times and found 17.  20.  25 fathoms --  In the afternoon a pleasant breeze from the N. & E.  Sunday 23.  The vessel rolling and pitching at a great rate, got up about 3 o'clock not being able to rest from knocking against the sides of my berth. --  By daylight the breeze increased almost to a gale.  Plenty of purpoises jumping about as is always the case when there is wind. --  Continued blowing all day. --

out of sight. --  Passed Cape San Antonio the most westerly part of the Island of Cuba distant about 12 miles. --  A very suspicious looking Sail in shore. --  Thursday 20th. --  The current or gulf stream sets in very strong to the northward here.  We have been sailing W. by S. since yesterday at noon and have made in 24 hours 54 miles of northing by our observation.  A great number of porpoises sporting round us -- They are from 9 to 10 feet long, with a snout like a hogs but longer; the tail keep a horizontal position unlike most other fishes.  The Surface of the water quite luminous from the number of fishes which appear to strikeout: fl lie floating on it. --  The appearance of these is very different from the illumination caused by the water breaking at night. --  The sea appears almost in a blaze from the porpoises sporting about. --  Friday 21st.  a A.M. a Sail in sight to the S.  Four very large pelicans flew by us, and on of the smallest birds I ever saw hovered about us a long time.  The coast of Yucatan in Sight; -- the lands is very low. --  Sounded last night in 25 fathoms, -- this morning in 13 and at noon in 8 fathoms. -- strikeout: The We can see the bottom clearly. --  The wind which ever

a short time. --  We put out and in other three times each time firing signals but they were of no avail. --  We observed five or six vessels near to an island about 6 miles to the S.E. of  Vera Cruz and made bold to steer our way to where they were and anchored among them at Lasacrificios. --  A boat manned by 18 Spaniards from the Castle of San Juan de Ulúa put off and boarded us, and the officer commanding desired the Capt. to proceed with him to the Castle.  One of the men spoke English very imperfectly.  The Capt. was preparing to proceed with him when an officer from the Cameleon Sloop of War, came along side and advised him not to go, giving us to understand that the Castle was in possession of the Spaniards & the only part held under the Spanish flag in the Country, and that the City of Vera Cruz was in a state of blockade, and should the Capt. be got once into the Castle he would be forced to pay duties to the Spanish Government and afterwards to the Mexican. --  The officer from the Castle returned without the Captain. --  Vera Cruz we were given to understand was completely abandoned by its population and all the merchants had removed to Alvarado to which port we prepared to Sail strikeout: for in the morning in Company of the Cameleon strikeout: next morning.

Monday 24th.  The wind a good deal abated.  A Sail to the N.W. steering to the eastward. --  The mate told the Captain that by his reckoning we ought to  make land by about midnight and advised heaving to in the evening, but the Capt. got highly offended at his presumption and insisted on continuing Sail till about nine o'clock when strikeout: l we hove to for the night, it being very dark. --  Tuesday 25th. --  Turned out of bed about 2 o'clock to breathe a little fresh air, and in in a few moments afterwards were all alarmed at the noise of the breakers which we were in fact drifting against, carried on by the current which set strongly in Shore. --  There was not a breath of wind and we were so near the reefs that we were almost certain of being driven upon them, and let down the anchor at 27 fathoms. --  The anchor would not take strikeout: fo bottom and we dragged it with us, our situation being most perilous. --  We got the anchor up and were within little more than a cable's length of the breakers when a small breeze from the shore  sprung up and enabled us to put out to sea. --  Went to strikeout: pe bed at 4 o'clock and got up again at 7. --  The Castle of San Juan de Silva strikeout: in Sea and the City of Vera Cruz in sight distant 9 or 10 miles. --  We kept in shore a l nearly as we could with safety and fired a gun for a pilot, hoisting a flag.  No pilot made his appearance and we put about again.  It commenced blowing and raining heavily, but the wind lasted only

of his questions in Spanish, and by making him write down what he wanted, by the help of a dictionary we managed to satisfy him. He was very polite and attentive and embraced us at parting. - The appearance of the  shore is uncomfortable; -- nothing but the bare beach with low sandhills in the background with here and there a patch of low shrubs, and about no appearance of inhabitants. --
Wednesday 26th, 1/2 past 4. 
Weighted anchor and sailed in Company with No one, Brig Chameleon? with very little wind. We kept ahead of the Cameleon till within 6 or 8 miles of Alvarado. The Forte Fugate (our convoy from Jamaica) with the brigs? Wahiont Caute, Francis, and Penn joined us here. The American Fugate the John Adams also unclear to cheif?. We hailed the Pam and they tell us that is eleven feet water on the bar, and as we ought

There had been no account of our Convoy.  There are anchored in Lasacrificios unclear the Cameleon, another British Vessel of War (a Cutter whose name I forgot) which had brough out the British Counsel General, a French Brig of War, and an English Merchant Ship. --  The Capt. and Campbell went ashore to see Wm. Neale acting British Counsel at Vera Cruz and the only foreigner then in the place, who confirmed what we had already heard of the necessity of our proceeding to Alvarado where all business was transacted. --  The City of Vera Cruz has suffered a severe bombardment from the Castle which had demolished many of its buildings and injured almost all of them. --  The appearance of the City from the water is beautiful it appears one continued mass of domes & spires. --  The Castle is situated about a mile off on an island which it almost entirely occupies. --  The Patriots have a fort at Point Mocambo in front of the island of Lasacrificios, and a boat put off from it manned by people who appeared to be  Indians, and we were boarded by the officer who noted the vessel's name and the Port of her Procedance, with the names of the Captain, passengers &c. [[strikeout: 3 lines + 1 word]  --1832.--  May 10th.  Left Guadalaxara for the Port of San Blas with the purpose of embarking for Guaymas in the State of Sonora, situated on the gulf of California. --  We started at 8 o'clock AM. and proceeded as far as "las pueblitos (three little groups of Indians about 4 leagues from Guadalaxara) in Coach, and then got on horseback. --  The road is infested with robbers & last night some hats were robbed. --  At eleven we arrived at the Venta or Inn del Astillero (7 leagues) where a Company of Dragoons was stationed for the protections of passengers.  The road from Guada. to this is a gentle rise all the way, and the country about almost entirely barren and scorched for the want of irrigation, the hills to the wood are bare of both wood and herbage.  An hour before sunset we arrived at the town of Armatitan, distant 8 leagues from the Astillero, but desiring to divide our journey to Tepic into four days, we proceeded to Tequila (3 leagues further), where we arrived late.  Armatitan is situated at the foot of a high hill & contains about one thousand inhabitants chiefly employed in the extraction of Vino mercel, a strong spirituous liquor resembling whiskey, extracted from the root of the Maguey or Agave Americana, which however is of a different sort from that whence Pulque is extracted;  This is much smaller and does not produce pulque

draw 10 feet we expect to get in tomorrow with the assistance of a pilot. --  Thursday 27th.  Went ashore in the Morning in the boat.  The Current was setting so strong out that we were carried Sideways among the breakers in great danger of being capsized. --  After two hours hard pulling we at last arrived at the town with no more injury than a good ducking from the spray. --  The town of Alvarado is situated  on the north bank of the river of the Same name about half a mile from its mouth, and in front of the town the river is about a mile broad, and perfectly safe from any wind. --  The north bank is composed of Sandhills, among which the town is situated, but on the south it is a deep swamp covered with a forest of bamboos and shrubs. --  Alvarado till now that the merchants from Vera Cruz have been obliged to take refuge in it, was little more than a fishing village. --  It contains about ten or twelve stone and brick houses and a church with a dome & spire with 5 or 6 bells, and two or three hundred houses or rather huts built of bamboo and wood.  The population consists of about three thousand of all possible shades and colors.  At present the place is healthy. --

In the neighbourhood there is also produced Corn, beans, chile, &c. sufficient for the consumption of the place.  Tequila is a large town containing about 7000 inhabitants and is beautifully situated at the end of an extensive plain; it is well built and has some very extensive distilleries. --  The Vegetation is luxuriant and the climate rather warmer that Guada.  A rivulet runs through the town. --  The hill or cerro de Tequila about 9 miles to the South, is about 6000 feet above the plain and wooded to the summit. --  I have seen this hill from San Antonio de Cerro gordo, 30 leagues to the other side if Guda. on the way to Mexico. --  On leaving Tequila May 11th. our strikeout: lead road leads zig-zig up the precipice behind the town, and for about 3 leagues lies what has more the appearance of the head of a mountain torrent running among low hills covered with small shrubs and brushwood.  Five leagues from Tequila is situated most beautifully the town of La Magdalena at the northern extremity of an extensive lake which reaches about 18 leagues to the S.E. and is from 1 to 2 leagues in width.  This beautiful lake has not even one boat or Canoe on it, and it produces a small white fish not very palatable. --  There are in the neighbourhood some gold and silver mines wrought on a very small scale
